alert.note: Alert for King; Pierce (Washington) Issued by the National Weather Service

info.headline: Flood Warning issued February 28 at 5:40PM PST until March 02 at 8:07AM PST by NWS Seattle
info.description: ...The National Weather Service in Seattle WA has issued a Flood Warning for the following rivers in Washington... White River At R Street Bridge affecting King and Pierce Counties. .A strong storm is impacting western Washington with multiple factors that will produce high runoff and flooding. Heavy, prolonged rainfall will be coupled with some snow snow melt in low to mid elevations of the mountains from rising snow levels and strong warm and moist winds. River rises on the White River below Mud Mountain Dam will combine with water coming out of the dam to rise to minor flood stage. Heavy rain will also threaten landslides and debris flows. ...FLOOD WARNING IN EFFECT FROM THIS EVENING TO WEDNESDAY MORNING... * WHAT...Minor flooding is forecast. * WHERE...White River At R Street Bridge. * WHEN...From this evening to Wednesday morning. * IMPACTS...At 7500.0 feet, River flooding is likely to occur near low bank areas around and downstream of the Stewart Streat Bridge in the city of Sumner. * ADDITIONAL DETAILS... - At 4:45 PM PST Monday the flow was 7200.0 cfs. - Forecast...The river is expected to rise to near flood stage this evening and will fluctuate near flood stage through Wednesday. It`s highest point may be tomorrow morning at around 7800 cfs, but will depend on reservoir operation changes and the local flows. It will then fall below flood stage for good and continue to fall Wednesday night. - Flood flow is 7500.0 cfs. - Flood History...This crest compares to a previous crest of 6400.0 cfs on 02/18/2020. - http://www.weather.gov/safety/flood &&
info.instruction: Motorists should not attempt to drive around barricades or drive cars through flooded areas. Caution is urged when walking near riverbanks. Turn around, don`t drown when encountering flooded roads. Most flood deaths occur in vehicles. Flooding is occurring or is imminent. Most flood related deaths occur in automobiles. Do not attempt to cross water covered bridges, dips, or low water crossings. Never try to cross a flowing stream, even a small one, on foot. To escape rising water find another route over higher ground. Additional information is available at www.weather.gov. The next statement will be issued by late tonight at 130 AM PST.
